Pico Projector Development Kit

Congratulations on your new DLP Pico Projector Development Kit. This is where you can find some demos to try it out with your BeagleBoard.

Initializing an SD card

With a Linux host

If you already have a Linux host, great. That means you are likely already familiar with most of the things required to make the most of your Pico Projector and BeagleBoard setup. You'll need to now acquire a 1GB or greater SD card and an adapter that works with your Linux host to configure Linux on your BeagleBoard.

Follow these steps:

  1. Download pico_sd_fat.tar.bz2.
  2. I'm actually using pico_sd_fat_new.tar.bz2 which has an updated u-boot.
  3. Download pico_sd_ext3.tar.bz2.
  4. Follow Nishanth’s instructions using gparted to partition and format the SD card.
  5. Be sure to copy MLO, u-boot.bin, uImage.bin, and boot.scr over to the FAT partition in that order.

Creating a Linux installation under Windows

Using 'dd' from any operating system

A 'dd' image can be created from Linux without access to an SD card, then written from any operating system where 'dd' can be run.

  1. Build the image using mkpicoimg.sh adjusting as necessary for the size of your SD card, location of your files, etc. --- or ---
  2. Simply download pico.img.gz.
  3. gzcat sd.img.gz | dd of= your device
